My favorite games in this package are Time Fcuck, Puzzle Platformer, Spewer, a puke-based platformer, and the original Super Meat Boy... it also has interviews with Edmund on most of the games, scenes taken out of Indie Game the Movie, concept art, soundtracks, and more! A ragtag collection of Ed McMillen's old flash games. If you liked playing all sorts of games on Newgrounds back in the day, like Ed McMillen's work, and want to see what his old games were like, I guess this might be for you. In all honestly, it was pretty hit and miss with me.

Coil was pretty abstract and didn't really give you instructions on what to do, which was the draw I suppose. Honestly wasn't too engaging.

Triachnid was pretty slow, and the physics can get really bothersome at times. Interesting atmosphere and way of telling it's story.

Meat Boy was pretty fun when it was on Newgrounds, and controlled pretty well at the time. But now after Super Meat Boy came out, it really doesn't hold up. The controls are really primitive and half the difficulty of the game is just fighting the controls. Several of these levels would be nowhere near as difficult if you put them into Super Meat Boy. Not really a fan of this one unfortunately. Super Meat Boy is just much better.

Time ♥♥♥♥ pretty much plays out like those old flash puzzle games. Kind of interesting and neat, and it did get a new set of levels in The Basement Collection. Unfortunately, those play out more like a ROM hack of this game instead of just being more levels fo play through. Those aren't really fun.

Spewer is my favorite from this collection of games. It's a puzzle platformer where your character has basically a barfing jetpack mechanic to help him get to certain places. The levels are pretty fun, and the main gimmick has plenty of ways to work out. Unfortunately, it can get a bit finnicky at times.

Aether is kind of a puzzle adventure game that's kind of interesting once you play through it. Unfortunately, finding the space landmarks for the achievements just isn't fun. Kind of interesting, but not much to it.

Grey Matter is a interesting game that I didn't find too engaging. It's a shooter type game, except you have to run into the enemies, and avoid the bullets. It was kind of fun, but I didn't have any real interest in the end.

A.V.G.M. is an unlockable game, that's a satire on cow clicker type games. The joke ran too far, and the joke itself wasn't that great.

Overall, a really mediocre collection. Get it if you're interested in Ed McMillen's old games, but there's really not much reason to get it otherwise.

I was interested in Edmund McMillen since I saw him in a documentary about game designers. I knew about Super Meat Boy, so I wanted to learn more about his style with this collection. So far I've only played Time ♥♥♥♥ so I'll talk about that:

This game is the best mindf*ck I've experienced in a looong while. It exemplifies the struggle of self and identity, reality, life and death. What I love most about it is the main antagonist, who seems to be you from the future: now trapped in this alternate dimension of maze-like rooms you find yourself in (which feels an awful lot like purgatory). As you go room to room and solve puzzles, this other self constantly puts you down and spouts all sorts of disturbing nonsense, while simulatenously cheering you on and pleading for help. Imagine something like an existentialist GLaDos, only crazier and more negative. If you can imagine that.

The game itself raises a multitude of philosophical questions and really makes you think deeply beyond the creative puzzles. The puzzles themselves can be maddening; the fact you have a limitless amount of lives and continues only adds to the sense of hopelessness, but you feel so fascinated and driven to keep going and solve each one, just to see what happens next...

reviewText:
I have been a fan of Edmund Mcmillen ever since he was back on Newgrounds, so the second I saw a compilation of all of those games redone come on sale, I was quite excited to jump back into the fray of the physics-platformers the man is known for, especially the original Meat Boy, which is fairly nostalgic to me.

Now, briefly, let me sum up the games: they're fine.
They're still well designed, sometimes brilliant little games that achieve so much with so little. I enjoy Spewer's, Time ♥♥♥♥'s, Aether's new smoother, crispier selves. Meat Boy was thrown under the bus.

Meat Boy is a very good game with consistent controls. These controls, while a tad floaty, are suited to the game's design. Meat Boy jumps just within the right height and width the character needs to see to the end of the level, turning this struggle into an elegant foray of taps and clicks. Every time you press the space bar, you feel in control of the hang time and brevity of the leap. It's simple and comfortable for a game with vertically designed levels in mind.

Super Meat Boy's levels are, for the most part, horizontal, and designed for a controller.

So, whoever decided to throw out the original controls in turn for these new ones is an idiot.
Meat Boy, as a game where it's levels are designed with the controls in mind, does NOT work with new controls.

Simple.

Now the game plays like an awkward, floppy piece of meat, where instead of dancing across levels, now feels as entertaining as swinging a stick around in a figure 8. Also, the stick is falling apart, constantly. As SOON as you let go of the space button, Meat Boy plummets to the ground as fast as he left. There is no arch like there was in the original, just because more people played Super Meat Boy and that's what they're used to.

And hey, on a controller, I'M used to that too! But guess what? No controller support!

AND, you can't change the controls back to the original!

MAN. I LIKE THIS REDESIGN.

Triachnid was unplayable due to the input lag on the controls,

Aether is a gravity-based physics platformer with a few puzzles to complete.  The music is good and there's some strange McMillen style story going on, if you're interested in this title it's available for free online (Newgrounds).

Time CFUK is a puzzle platformer that deals with alternate dimentions or time travel or something.  It's actually pretty well put-together and I'd say is the highlight of the games in the collection.  I found the strange storyline appealing.  This is available for free online as well.

Spewer is a physics-based platformer where you puke out goo that you use to navigate the levels.  It's alright, your typical flash-based game.   Once again, available for free online.

Meat Boy - the prequel to Super Meat Boy.  Super Meat Boy is great because of its tight controls. reviewText: The Basement Collection is a great little, well, as it says, collection of games Edmund McMillan has previously released or never released before. Aether is great, Coil is a little... deep, but still just as great, as are other titles in this small collection. There's also small bonus content where Edmund's wife interviews him about each of the games and each of the most commonly asked questions about said games are included as well, which is great to listen to. There's also sketch and concept art of each game included. I'd reccomend this to anyone who is a big fan of Edmund's other works like Super Meat Boy and Binding of Isaac. If you aren't a fan, however, then this pack is not for you, simple as that.
